author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: What we think Christmas is will determine how we observe it and whether we enjoy it.
title: The Origin Story

sections.text: What we think Christmas is will determine how we observe it and whether we enjoy it. The traditional word for this season is actually Advent, and it means “coming.” Historically, Christians have observed the Advent season by celebrating not only  Christ’s first coming but also anticipating his second coming. So, to truly experience the meaning of Christmas is to remember how and why Jesus came in the flesh and to reflect on his promises to return.

More than the accomplishments we achieve, our heritage is part of who we are. This can be disappointing if we don’t come from an “ideal” family situation (whatever that looks like). It can also be a dangerous source of pride for us if we put too much emphasis on our background. Our ethnic and familial heritage is part of who we are, but it is not the whole of who we are meant to be. Regardless of your earthly heritage, the history recorded in Matthew chapter one is important for you. This is your ancestry, your story, if you are in Christ. So read it as if it is your own family history! And if you are not yet united to Christ, this can become your story through faith in him.

My hope is that by reading these short devotions, you will see the wisdom of God’s perfect plan of redemption brought about through imperfect people. I hope you will recapture the wonder of Christ’s birth, not as mere happenstance but as a promise fulfilled by the God who oversees all of history. I hope that you will better comprehend how all of Scripture points to Jesus. And I hope that this will help you remember the true meaning of the Advent season as you look back to Jesus’ first coming and long for his return!

author: Jeremy Brown
seriesTitle: Anticipating the Savior – 25 days of Advent
cardDescription: The origin story of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham. Matthew 1:1
title: Day 2

sections.text: David was the greatest king of Israel, the one who ruled from a heart that feared God above all others. The tiny nation of Israel never knew such blessing, security, and prominence as when David was king. David even became the very standard by which all other kings in Israel were measured because only under David did Israel rightly worship the LORD. In fact, what it meant to be a “son of David” was not merely to be his descendant but to rule in the fear of the Lord the way that David did. In

, God promised King David, “And your house and your kingdom shall be made sure forever before me. Your throne shall be established forever.” How could this be? How would David’s rule last forever? Only through his greater Son. Christ is the fulfillment of God’s promise to King David. The Scripture is clear that David’s righteous rule was always pointing forward to a coming King who would rule perfectly and permanently.
When God said to Abraham, “…in you all the families of the earth shall be blessed…” it was through a particular descendant that God intended to make good on this promise

sections.test: It was the Jews who were the chosen people of God from all the nations of the earth, but through Jesus, God expanded his chosen family to include people from every nation, every language, every tribe. Now, through faith in Jesus Christ, anyone, regardless of their ethnic or family heritage, can become a child of God. 'He came to his own, and his own people did not receive him. But to all who did receive him, who believed in his name, he gave the right to become children of God, who were born not of blood, nor of the will of the flesh, nor of the will of man but of God.'

sections.text: As the son of Abraham, Jesus is the one through whom anyone can become a child of God. As the son of David, Jesus is the promised ruler who has inaugurated and will establish a new kingdom of peace and prosperity that will last forever! In Jesus, the Light of the world has broken through the darkness of sin and suffering in this world. No matter our circumstances this Advent season, we can celebrate with joy and hope, knowing that the hero we need has already come! And because he came the first time to redeem his fallen creation, we can trust that he will come again to restore it fully and finally!

Prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for sending us your Son, who identifies with us in our weaknesses but also rules over us in the strength of your steadfast love! Help us to be in awe that you would come down to us in this way! AMEN!
